user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of get_timeout_millisec_int:
```c
static int
get_timeout_millisec_int (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                          int32_t max_timeout)
{
  int64_t res;

  res = get_timeout_millisec_ (daemon, max_timeout);
#if SIZEOF_INT < SIZEOF_INT64_T
  if (INT_MAX <= res)
    return INT_MAX;
#endif /* SIZEOF_INT < SIZEOF_INT64_T */
  return (int) res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
  res = get_timeout_millisec_ (daemon, max_timeout);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the shown fragment: get_timeout_millisec_int calls get_timeout_millisec_ which is a different function name, so there is no direct self-call. This would only violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 if get_timeout_millisec_ were actually an alias to get_timeout_millisec_int (e.g. via a macro or rename) or if get_timeout_millisec_ (possibly elsewhere) calls back get_timeout_millisec_int, creating indirect recursion.
